{{recentism|date=September 2018}} <!-- appeals to emotion regardless of facts have been happening in democracies and other societies for hundreds of years --> {{short description|Political culture where facts are considered of low relevance}} {{EngvarB|date=August 2016}} {{use dmy dates|date=November 2016}} '''Post-truth politics''' (also called '''post-factual politics'''<ref name="Schwartz">{{cite web|title=George Will: "Post-Factual Politics" From Campaign Still Exists, Nixon More Of A Statesman Than Current Leadership|date=28 November 2016|accessdate=8 November 2017|first=Ian|last=Schwartz|url=https://www.realclearpolitics.com/video/2016/11/28/george_will_post-factual_politics_from_campaign_nixon_statesman_trump.html|publisher=[[RealClearPolitics.com]]}}</ref> and '''post-reality politics''')<ref name="Holmes">{{cite news|date=26 September 2016|accessdate=8 November 2017|newspaper=[[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire]]|url=http://www.esquire.com/news-politics/news/a48906/trump-campaign-manager-lester-holt/|title=Trump's Campaign Manager Offered Her Most Brilliant Defense Yet of Trump's Lies|first=Jack|last=Holmes}}</ref> is a [[political culture]] in which debate is framed largely by [[appeal to emotion|appeals to emotion]] disconnected from the details of [[public policy|policy]], and by the repeated assertion of [[talking point]]s to which factual rebuttals are ignored. [[wiktionary:post-truth|Post-truth]] differs from traditional contesting and falsifying of facts by relegating facts and expert opinions to be of secondary importance relative to appeal to emotion. While this has been described as a contemporary problem, some observers have described it as a long-standing part of political life that was less notable before the advent of the [[Internet]] and related social changes.
{{As of|2018}} political commentators have identified post-truth politics as ascendant in many nations, notably the United States, India, the United Kingdom, Russia, and Brazil, among others. As with other areas of debate, this is being driven by a combination of the [[24-hour news cycle]], [[false balance]] in news reporting, and the increasing ubiquity of [[social media]].<ref name=economist-10-9-16>{{cite web|url=https://www.economist.com/news/briefing/21706498-dishonesty-politics-nothing-new-manner-which-some-politicians-now-lie-and |title="The post-truth world: Yes, I’d lie to you," ''The Economist'' Sept 10, 2016 |publisher=Economist.com |date=2016-09-10 |accessdate=2018-03-26}}</ref><ref name="Age-abbott">{{cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/comment/tony-abbotts-carbon-tax-outrage-signals-nadir-of-posttruth-politics-20140717-ztz2b.html|title=Tony Abbott's carbon tax outrage signals nadir of post-truth politics |date=14 July 2014|accessdate=11 July 2016|author=John Connor|newspaper=The Age}}</ref><ref name="Age-futile"/><ref name="TOI-brexit-trump">{{cite news|url=http://blogs.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/to-name-and-address/everything-but-the-truth-what-we-share-with-the-brexit-campaign-and-trump/|title=Life in post-truth times: What we share with the Brexit campaign and Trump|date=30 June 2016|author=Amulya Gopalakrishnan|accessdate=11 July 2016|newspaper=The Times of India}}</ref><ref name="Dunt"/><ref name="NSci-revolut">{{cite news|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg23030763-000-free-speech-has-become-sound-bites-with-revolutionary-results/|title=Free speech has met social media, with revolutionary results|date=1 June 2016|newspaper=New Scientist|accessdate=11 July 2016}}</ref> In 2016, ''post-truth'' was chosen as the [[Oxford word of the year|Oxford Dictionaries' Word of the Year]],<ref name="wordofyear"/> due to its prevalence in the context of that year's [[United Kingdom European Union membership referendum, 2016|Brexit referendum]] and media coverage of the [[United States presidential election, 2016|U.S. presidential election]].<ref name="Freedland-nojoke"/><ref name="WaPo-era"/>
==History== According to [[OxfordDictionaries.com|Oxford Dictionaries]], the term ''post-truth'' was first used in a 1992 essay by the late Serbian-American playwright [[Steve Tesich]] in ''[[The Nation]]''. Tesich writes that following the shameful truth of [[Watergate]], more assuaging coverage of the [[Iran–Contra scandal]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nsarchive.gwu.edu/NSAEBB/NSAEBB567-Iran-Contra-Reagan-Oliver-North-and-Post-Truth-30-years-later/ |title=The Iran-Contra Affair 30 Years Later: A Milestone in Post-Truth Politics |work=National Security Archive|date=25 November 2016|accessdate=24 May 2017}}</ref> and [[Gulf War|Persian Gulf War]] demonstrate that "we, as a free people, have freely decided that we want to live in some post-truth world."<ref>{{cite web | url =https://www.theguardian.com/books/2016/nov/15/post-truth-named-word-of-the-year-by-oxford-dictionaries| title= 'Post-truth' named word of the year by Oxford Dictionaries| first=Alison | last=Flood | date = 15 November 2016 | accessdate = 20 November 2016|work=The Guardian}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Kreitner |first=Richard |url=https://www.thenation.com/article/post-truth-and-its-consequences-what-a-25-year-old-essay-tells-us-about-the-current-moment/ |title=Post-Truth and Its Consequences: What a 25-Year-Old Essay Tells Us About the Current Moment |date=30 November 2016 |work=The Nation |accessdate=1 December 2016}}</ref> In 2004, [[Ralph Keyes (author)|Ralph Keyes]] used the term "post-truth era" in his book by that title.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Keyes|first1=Ralph|title=The Post-Truth Era: Dishonesty and Deception in Contemporary Life|date=2004|publisher=[[St. Martin's Press|St. Martin's]]|location=New York}}</ref> The same year American journalist [[Eric Alterman]] spoke of a "post-truth political environment" and coined the term "the post-truth presidency" in his analysis of the misleading statements made by the [[Presidency of George W. Bush|Bush administration]] after 9/11.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Alterman|first1=Eric|title=When Presidents Lie: A History of Official Deception and Its Consequences|date=2004|publisher=[[Viking Press|Viking]]|location=New York|page=305}}</ref> In his 2004 book ''Post-democracy'', Colin Crouch used the phrase "post-democracy" to mean a model of politics where "elections certainly exist and can change governments," but "public electoral debate is a tightly controlled spectacle, managed by rival teams of professionals expert in the techniques of persuasion, and considering a small range of issues selected by those teams." Crouch directly attributes the "advertising industry model" of political communication to the crisis of trust and accusations of dishonesty that a few years later others have associated with post-truth politics.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Crouch|first1=Colin|title=Post-democracy|date=2004|publisher=[[Polity (publisher)|Polity]]|location=Cambridge, UK|page=4}}</ref>
The term "post-truth politics" was coined by the blogger David Roberts in a blog post for ''[[Grist (magazine)|Grist]]'' on 1 April 2010, where it was defined as "a political culture in which politics (public opinion and media [[narrative]]s) have become almost entirely disconnected from policy (the substance of legislation)".<ref name="HuffCoinage">{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/tom-jeffery/britain-needs-more-democr_b_10699898.html|title=Britain Needs More Democracy After the EU Referendum, Not Less|author=Tom Jeffery|date=26 June 2016|accessdate=11 July 2016|website=The Huffington Post}}</ref><ref name="Coining">{{cite news|url=http://grist.org/article/2010-03-30-post-truth-politics/|title=Post-Truth Politics|date=1 April 2010|website=Grist|accessdate=11 July 2016}}</ref> Post truth was used by philosopher [[Joseph Heath]] to describe the [[2014 Ontario election]]. The term became widespread during the campaigns for the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 presidential election]] in the United States and the [[United Kingdom European Union membership referendum, 2016|2016 "Brexit" referendum on membership in the European Union]] in the United Kingdom.<ref name="Freedland-nojoke"/><ref name="WaPo-era"/> [[OxfordDictionaries.com|Oxford Dictionaries]] declared that its international word of the year in 2016 is "post-truth", citing a 2,000% increase in usage compared to 2015.<ref name="wordofyear">{{cite web |last=Flood |first=Alison |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2016/nov/15/post-truth-named-word-of-the-year-by-oxford-dictionaries |title='Post-truth' named word of the year by Oxford Dictionaries |work=The Guardian |date=15 November 2016 |accessdate=16 November 2016}}</ref>
Jennifer Hochschild, H.L. Jayne Professor of Government at [[Harvard University]], has described the rise of post-truth as a return to 18th and 19th century political and media practices in the United States, following a period in the 20th century where the media was relatively balanced and rhetoric was toned down.<ref name="Harvard-politics">{{cite news|url=http://news.harvard.edu/gazette/story/2016/07/politics-in-a-post-truth-age/|title=Politics in a 'post-truth' age|newspaper=[[Harvard Gazette]]|date=14 July 2016|accessdate=6 August 2016|author= Christina Pazzanese}}</ref> (Not so in Britain and elsewhere necessarily; for example, in 1957 scientist [[Kathleen Lonsdale]] remarked that "for many people truthfulness in politics has now become a mockery.... Anyone who listens to the radio in a mixed company of thinking people knows how deep-seated is this cynicism." <ref>Kathleen Lonsdale, ''Is Peace Possible?'' by Penguin Books, 1957, p 11</ref>)
The [[pamphlet wars]] that arose with the growth of printing and literacy beginning in the 1600s have been described as an early form of post-truth politics. Slanderous and vitriolic pamphlets were cheaply printed and widely disseminated, and the dissent that they fomented contributed to starting wars and revolutions such as the [[English Civil War]] and the [[American War of Independence]].<ref name="NSci-revolut"/>
==Description== {{Synthesis|section|date=February 2017}} [[File:EU referendum leave poster, Belfast, June 2016 - geograph.org.uk - 4990237.jpg|thumb|250px|A [[Vote Leave]] poster with a contested claim about the EU membership fee, cited as an example of post-truth politics.<ref name="Wollaston">{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/entry/tory-mp-sarah-wollaston-switches-sides-in-eu-referendum-campaign_uk_57587e00e4b0415143693876|title=Tory MP Sarah Wollaston Switches Sides in EU Referendum Campaign|date=8 June 2016|accessdate=11 July 2016|website=The Huffington Post|author=Ned Simons}}</ref>]] A defining trait of post-truth politics is that campaigners continue to repeat their talking points, even when media outlets, experts in the field in question, and others provide proof that contradicts these talking points.<ref name="Preston">{{cite news|title=Broadcast news is losing its balance in the post-truth era|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2012/sep/09/post-truth-politics-us-broadcasting|date=9 September 2012|accessdate=11 July 2016|author=Peter Preston|newspaper=The Guardian}}</ref> For example, during campaigning for the British EU referendum campaign, [[Vote Leave]] made repeated use of the claim that EU membership cost £350 million a week, although later began to use the figure as a net amount of money sent directly to the EU. This figure, which ignored the [[UK rebate]] and other factors, was described as "potentially misleading" by the [[UK Statistics Authority]], as "not sensible" by the [[Institute for Fiscal Studies]], and was rejected in fact checks by [[BBC News]], [[Channel 4 News]] and [[Full Fact]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://fullfact.org/europe/our-eu-membership-fee-55-million/|title=The UK's EU membership fee|website=Full Fact|date=27 May 2016|accessdate=11 July 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-eu-referendum-36040060|title=Reality Check: Would Brexit mean extra £350m a week for NHS?|author=Anthony Reuben|publisher=BBC News|date=25 April 2016|accessdate=11 July 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://blogs.channel4.com/factcheck/factcheck-send-350m-week-brussels/22804|title=FactCheck: do we really send £350m a week to Brussels?|author=Patrick Worrall|date=19 April 2016|accessdate=11 July 2016|website=Channel 4 News|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160708115949/http://blogs.channel4.com/factcheck/factcheck-send-350m-week-brussels/22804|archivedate=8 July 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Vote Leave nevertheless continued to use the figure as a centrepiece of their campaign until the day of the referendum, after which point they downplayed the pledge as having been an "example", pointing out that it was only ever suggested as a possible alternative use of the net funds sent to the EU.<ref name="ind11">{{cite news|last1=Stone|first1=Jon|title=Vote Leave's £350m for the NHS pledge was ‘just an example’, says group's chair|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/gisela-stuart-vote-leaves-350m-for-the-nhs-pledge-was-just-an-example-the-groups-chair-says-a7238451.html|accessdate=16 November 2016|work=The Independent|date=12 September 2016}}</ref> Tory MP and Leave campaigner [[Sarah Wollaston]], who left the group in protest during its campaign, criticised its "post-truth politics".<ref name="Wollaston"/>
[[Michael Deacon (journalist)|Michael Deacon]], [[parliamentary sketch writing|parliamentary sketchwriter]] for ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'', summarised the core message of post-truth politics as "Facts are negative. Facts are pessimistic. Facts are unpatriotic." He added that post-truth politics can also include a claimed rejection of [[Polarization (politics)|partisanship]] and [[negative campaigning]].<ref name="Deacon">{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/07/09/in-a-world-of-post-truth-politics-andrea-leadsom-will-make-the-p/|title=In a world of post-truth politics, Andrea Leadsom will make the perfect PM |author=Michael Deacon|date=9 July 2016|accessdate=11 July 2016|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph}}</ref> In this context, campaigners can push a [[utopia]]n "positive campaign" to which rebuttals can be dismissed as [[Smear campaign|smears]] and [[scaremongering]] and opposition as partisan.<ref name="Coining"/><ref name="Deacon"/>
In its most extreme mode, post-truth politics can make use of [[conspiracism]].<ref name="Humanists">{{cite magazine|url=http://thehumanist.com/magazine/january-february-2016/church-state/humanists-rise-post-truth-america|title=Humanists and the Rise of "Post-Truth America"|author=Roy Boston|date=22 December 2015|accessdate=11 July 2016|magazine=The Humanist}}</ref><ref name="Indy">{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/donald-trump-campaign-republican-us-election-2016-what-it-says-about-a7022276.html|title=Donald Trump's post-truth campaign and what it says about the dismal state of US politics|author=Chris Cillizza|date=10 May 2016|accessdate=11 July 2016|newspaper=The Independent}}</ref> In this form of post-truth politics, false rumors (such as the "[[Barack Obama citizenship conspiracy theories|birther]]" or "[[Barack Obama religion conspiracy theories|Muslim]]" conspiracy theories about Barack Obama) become major news topics.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Harsin|first1=Jayson|title=That's Democratainment: Obama, Rumor Bombs and Primary Definers|url=http://www.flowjournal.org/2010/10/thats-democratainment/|website=Flow TV|accessdate=31 August 2016}}</ref> In the case of the "[[Pizzagate conspiracy theory|pizzagate]]" conspiracy, this resulted in a man entering the Comet Ping Pong pizzeria and firing an [[AR-15]] rifle.<ref>Kang, Cecilia, A. D. A. M. Goldman, and WASHINGTON—Edgar M. Welch. "In Washington pizzeria attack, fake news brought real guns." ''The New York Times'' 5 (2016).</ref>
In contrast to simply telling untruths, writers such as Jack Holmes of ''[[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire]]'' describe the process as something different, with Holmes putting it as: "So, if you don't know what's true, you can say whatever you want and it's not a lie".<ref name="Holmes"/>
==Drivers== In 2015 media and Politics scholar Jayson Harsin coined the term "regime of post-truth" which encompasses many aspects of post-truth politics. He argues that a convergent set of developments have created the conditions of post-truth society: the political communication informed by cognitive science, which aims at managing perception and belief of segmented populations through techniques like [[microtargeting]] which includes the strategic use of [[Rumor#Political communication strategy|rumors]] and falsehoods; the fragmentation of modern, more centralized mass news media gatekeepers, which have largely repeated one another's scoops and their reports; the attention economy marked by information overload and acceleration, user-generated content and fewer society-wide common trusted authorities to distinguish between truth and lies, accurate and inaccurate; the algorithms which govern what appears in social media and search engine rankings, based on what users want (per algorithm) and not on what is factual; and news media which have been marred by scandals of plagiarism, hoaxes, propaganda, and changing news values. These developments have occurred on the background of economic crises, downsizing and favoring trends toward more traditional [[Tabloid (newspaper format)|tabloid]] stories and [[Tabloid journalism|styles of reporting]], known as tabloidization<ref>Frank Esser [http://ejc.sagepub.com/content/14/3/291.short?rss=1&ssource=mfc `Tabloidization' of News. A Comparative Analysis of Anglo-American and German Press Journalism] European Journal of Communication Vol 14, Issue 3, 1999 September 1, 1999</ref> and [[infotainment]].
While some of these phenomena (such as a more tabloidesque press) may suggest a return to the past, the effect of the convergences is a socio-political phenomenon which exceeds earlier forms of journalism in deliberate distortion and struggle. Fact-checking and rumor-busting sites abound, but they are unable to reunite a fragmented set of audiences (attention-wise) and their respective trustful-/distrustfulness. Harsin has called it a "regime of post-truth" instead of merely post-truth politics, professional pan-partisan political communication manipulates the communication competitively.<ref>{{cite journal|date=24 February 2015|title=Regimes of Posttruth, Postpolitics, and Attention Economies|journal=Communication, Culture & Critique|volume=8|issue=2|pages=327–333|last1=Harsin|first1=Jayson}}</ref>
=== Major news outlets === Several trends in the media landscape have been blamed for the perceived rise of post-truth politics. One contributing factor has been the proliferation of state-funded news agencies like [[CCTV News]] and [[RT (TV network)|RT]], and [[Voice of America]] in the USA which allow states to influence [[Western world|Western]] audiences. According to [[Peter Pomerantsev]], a British-Russian journalist who worked for [[TNT (Russian TV channel)|TNT]] in Moscow, one of their prime objectives has been to de-legitimize Western institutions, including the structures of government, democracy, and human rights.{{citation needed|date=December 2016}} As of 2016, trust in the mainstream media in the US had reached historical lows.<ref name="WaPo-era">{{cite news|title=Why the post-truth political era might be around for a while|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/posteverything/wp/2016/06/16/why-the-post-truth-political-era-might-be-around-for-a-while/|author=[[Daniel W. Drezner]]|date=16 June 2016|accessdate=11 July 2016|newspaper=The Washington Post}}</ref> It has been suggested that under these conditions, [[Fact checker|fact checking]] by news outlets struggles to gain traction among the wider public<ref name="WaPo-era" /><ref>{{cite web|title=Delivering trust: Impartiality and objectivity in the digital age|date=January 2012|author=Richard Sambrook|url=http://orca.cf.ac.uk/33772/1/Delivering_Trust_Impartiality_and_Objectivity_in_a_Digital_Age.pdf|website=Reuters Institute for the Study of Journalism|publisher=University of Oxford}}</ref> and that politicians resort to increasingly drastic messaging.<ref name="Age-futile">{{cite news|title=Facts are futile in an era of post-truth politics|url=http://www.theage.com.au/comment/facts-are-futile-in-an-era-of-posttruth-politics-20140227-33m70.html|author=Gay Alcorn|newspaper=The Age|date=27 February 2014|accessdate=11 July 2016}}</ref>
Many news outlets desire to appear to be, or have a policy of being, [[impartiality|impartial]]. Many writers have noted that in some cases, this leads to [[false balance]], the practice of giving equal emphasis to unsupported or discredited claims without challenging their factual basis.<ref> *Robert S. Eshelman, [http://archives.cjr.org/essay/the_danger_of_fair_and_balance.php The danger of fair and balanced], ''Columbia Journalism Review'' (May 1, 2014). *Peter Preston, [https://www.theguardian.com/media/2012/sep/09/post-truth-politics-us-broadcasting Broadcast news is losing its balance in the post-truth era], ''The Guardian'' (September 9, 2012). *[[Margaret Sullivan (journalist)|Margaret Sullivan]], [https://www.nytimes.com/2012/09/16/public-editor/16pubed.html He Said, She Said, and the Truth], ''New York Times'' (September 15, 2012): "Simply put, false balance is the journalistic practice of giving equal weight to both sides of a story, regardless of an established truth on one side." *[[Paul Krugman]], [https://www.nytimes.com/2011/12/23/opinion/krugman-the-post-truth-campaign.html The Post-Truth Campaign], ''New York Times'' (December 23, 2011): "[I]f past experience is any guide, most of the news media will feel as though their reporting must be 'balanced,' which means that every time they point out that a Republican lied they have to match it with a comparable accusation against a Democrat — even if what the Democrat said was actually true or, at worst, a minor misstatement." *[[Katrina vanden Heuvel]], [https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/katrina-vanden-heuvel-the-distorting-reality-of-false-balance-in-the-media/2014/07/14/6def5706-0b81-11e4-b8e5-d0de80767fc2_story.html The distorting reality of 'false balance' in the media], ''Washington Post'': "False equivalence in the media — giving equal weight to unsupported or even discredited claims for the sake of appearing impartial — is not unusual. But a major media organization taking meaningful steps to do something about it is."</ref> The 24-hour news cycle also means that news channels repeatedly draw on the same public figures, which benefits PR-savvy politicians and means that presentation and personality can have a larger impact on the audience than facts,<ref>{{cite book|title=The Post-Truth Era: Dishonesty and Deception in Contemporary Life|pages=127–128|year=2004|author=Ralph Keyes|isbn=9781429976220}}</ref> while the process of claim and counter-claim can provide grist for days of news coverage at the expense of deeper analysis of the case.<ref name="TOI-brexit-trump"/>
=== Social media and the Internet === [[Social media]] adds an additional dimension, as user networks can become [[Echo chamber (media)|echo chambers]] possibly emphasised by the [[filter bubble]] where one political viewpoint dominates and scrutiny of claims fails,<ref name="TOI-brexit-trump" /><ref name="NSci-revolut" /><ref name="FT-trust">{{cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/24035fc2-3e45-11e6-9f2c-36b487ebd80a.html|title=Why we no longer trust the experts|date=1 July 2016|author=Gillian Tett|accessdate=11 July 2016|newspaper=Financial Times}}</ref> allowing a parallel [[media ecosystem]] of websites, publishers and news channels to develop, which can repeat post-truth claims without rebuttal.<ref name="Humanist">{{cite news|url=http://thehumanist.com/magazine/january-february-2016/church-state/humanists-rise-post-truth-america|title=Humanists and the Rise of "Post-Truth America"|date=22 December 2015|author=Rob Boston|accessdate=6 August 2016|newspaper=The Humanist}}</ref> In this environment, post-truth campaigns can ignore fact checks or dismiss them as being motivated by bias.<ref name="Indy" /> ''[[The Guardian]]'' editor-in-chief [[Katherine Viner]] laid some of the blame on the rise of [[clickbait]], articles of dubious factual content with a misleading headline and which are designed to be widely shared, saying that "chasing down cheap clicks at the expense of accuracy and veracity" undermines the value of journalism and truth.<ref name="Viner">{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/jul/12/how-technology-disrupted-the-truth| title=How technology disrupted the truth| date=12 July 2016|accessdate=12 July 2016|newspaper=The Guardian|author=Katherine Viner}}</ref> In 2016, David Mikkelson, co-founder of the [[fact checking]] and [[debunking]] site ''[[Snopes.com]]'', described the introduction of social media and [[fake news sites]] as a turning point, saying "I’m not sure I’d call it a post-truth age but … there’s been an opening of the sluice-gate and everything is pouring through. The bilge keeps coming faster than you can pump."<ref name="snopes">{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/aug/01/snopes-com-internet-fact-checker-post-truth-david-mikkelson| title=Can mythbusters like Snopes.com keep up in a post-truth era?| date=1 August 2016|author=Rory Carroll|accessdate=23 October 2016|newspaper=The Guardian}}</ref>
The digital culture allows anybody with a computer and access to the internet to post their opinions online and mark them as fact which may become legitimized through echo-chambers and other users validating one another. Content may be judged based on how many views a post gets, creating an atmosphere that appeals to emotion, audience biases, or headline appeal instead of researched fact. Content which gets more views is continually filtered around different internet circles, regardless of its legitimacy. Some also argue that the abundance of fact available at any time on the internet leads to an attitude focused on knowing basic claims to information instead of an underlying truth or formulating carefully thought-out opinions.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://opentranscripts.org/transcript/post-truth-politics/|title=Is Digital Culture Responsible for Post-Truth Politics? - Eliane Glaser {{!}} Open Transcripts|work=Open Transcripts|access-date=2017-03-03|language=en-US}}</ref> The internet allows people to choose where they get their information, allowing them to reinforce their own opinions.<ref name="auto">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/24/opinion/campaign-stops/the-age-of-post-truth-politics.html|title=The Age of Post-Truth Politics|last=Davies|first=William|date=2016-08-24|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-03-03|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>
=== Polarized political culture === The rise of post-truth politics coincides with polarized political beliefs. A [[Pew Research Center]] study of American adults found that "those with the most consistent ideological views on the left and right have information streams that are distinct from those of individuals with more mixed political views—and very distinct from each other".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Amy Mitchell|first1=Amy|last2=Kiley|first2=Jocelyn|last3=Eva Matsa|first3=Katerina|last4=Gottfied|first4=Jeffrey|title=Political Polarization & Media Habits|url=http://www.journalism.org/2014/10/21/political-polarization-media-habits/|publisher=Pew Research Center|accessdate=31 August 2016}}</ref> Data is becoming increasingly accessible as new technologies are introduced to the everyday lives of citizens. An obsession for data and statistics also filters into the political scene, and political debates and speeches become filled with snippets of information that may be misconstrued, false, or not contain the whole picture. Sensationalized television news emphasizes grand statements and further publicizes politicians. This shaping from the media influences how the public views political issues and candidates.<ref name="auto"/>
== Dissenting views ==
In an editorial, ''[[New Scientist]]'' suggested "a cynic might wonder if politicians are actually any more dishonest than they used to be", and hypothesized that "fibs once whispered into select ears are now overheard by everyone".<ref name="NSci-revolut"/> Similarly, Viner suggested that while social media has helped some untruths to spread, it has also restrained others; as an example, she said ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]''{{'}}s false "[[Hillsborough disaster#The Sun|The Truth]]" story following the [[Hillsborough disaster]], and the associated police cover-up, would be hard to imagine in the social media age.<ref name="Viner"/> The journalist George Gillett has suggested that the term "post-truth" mistakenly conflates empirical and ethical judgements, writing that the supposedly "post-truth" movement is in fact a rebellion against "expert economic opinion becoming a surrogate for values-based political judgements".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://georgegillett.com/2017/04/20/the-myth-of-post-truth-politics/|title=The myth of post-truth politics|date=20 April 2017|publisher=}}</ref>
[[Toby Young]], writing for ''[[The Spectator]]'', called the term a "cliché" used selectively primarily by [[left-wing]] commentators to attack what are actually universal [[Confirmation bias|ideological bias]]es, contending that "[w]e are all post-truthers and probably always have been".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.spectator.co.uk/2016/07/the-truth-about-post-truth-politics/|title=The truth about 'post-truth politics'|date=16 July 2016<!-- Print date, presumably - web article was online earlier-->|accessdate=14 July 2016|author=Toby Young|newspaper=The Spectator}}</ref> ''[[The Economist]]'' has called this argument "complacent", however, identifying a qualitative difference between political scandals of previous generations, such as those surrounding the [[Suez Crisis]] and the [[Iran–Contra affair]] (which involved attempting to cover-up the truth) and contemporary ones in which public facts are simply ignored.<ref name=economist-10-9-16/> Similarly, Alexios Mantzarlis of the [[Poynter Institute]] said that political lies were not new and identified several political campaigns in history which would now be described as "post-truth". For Mantzarlis, the "post-truth" label was—to some extent—a "[[coping mechanism]] for commentators reacting to attacks on not just any facts, but on those central to their belief system", but also noted that 2016 had been "an acrimonious year for politics on both sides of the Atlantic".<ref name="Poynter">{{cite web|url=http://www.poynter.org/2016/no-were-not-in-a-post-fact-era/421582/|title=No, we’re not in a ‘post-fact’ era|date=21 July 2016|accessdate=27 October 2016|author=Alexios Mantzarlis|website=Poynter Institute}}</ref> Mantzarlis also noted that interest in [[fact checking]] had never been higher, suggesting that at least part of the electorate rejects "post-truth" politics.<ref name="Poynter"/><ref name="WP">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/fact-check-this-is-not-really-a-post-fact-election/2016/10/07/7ef5f8fa-85c0-11e6-92c2-14b64f3d453f_story.html|title=Fact check: This is not really a post-fact election|publisher=Washington Post|date=7 October 2016|accessdate=27 October 2016|author=Alexios Mantzarlis}}</ref>
[[David Helfand]] argues, following Edward M. Harris, that "public prevarication is nothing new" and that it is the "knowledge of the audience" and the "limits of plausibility" within a technology-saturated environment that have changed. We are, rather, in an age of misinformation where such limits of plausibility have vanished and where everyone feels equally qualified to make claims that are easily shared and propagated.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Helfand |first1=David J. |authorlink1=David Helfand |title=Surviving the Misinformation Age |journal=[[Skeptical Inquirer]] |date=2017 |volume=41 |issue=3 |pages=34-39 |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181006193643/https://www.csicop.org/si/show/surviving_the_misinformation_age |accessdate=6 October 2018}}</ref>
==Examples== Post-truth politics has been applied as a political buzzword to a wide range of political cultures; one article in ''The Economist'' identified post-truth politics in [[Austria]], [[Germany]], [[North Korea]], [[Poland]], [[Russia]], [[Turkey]], the [[United Kingdom]], and the [[United States]].<ref name=economist-10-9-16/>
===Germany===
In December 2016 "[[:de:Postfaktische Politik|postfaktisch]]" (post-factual) was named word of the year by the ''[[Gesellschaft für deutsche Sprache]]'' (''German language society''), also in connection with a rise of [[right-wing populism]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gfds.de/wort-des-jahres-2016/|title=GfdS wählt »postfaktisch« zum Wort des Jahres 2016|date=9 December 2016|publisher=}}</ref> from [[Alternative for Germany#Petry assumes leadership, Lucke quits|2015]] on. Since the 1990s, "[[Colin Crouch#Post Democracy|post-democracy]]" was used in sociology more and more.
===India=== Amulya Gopalakrishnan, columnist for ''[[The Times of India]]'', identified similarities between the Trump and Brexit campaigns on the one hand, and [[hot-button issue]]s in India such as the [[Ishrat Jahan case]] and the ongoing case against [[Teesta Setalvad]] on the other, where accusations of forged evidence and [[historical revisionism]] have resulted in an "ideological impasse".<ref name="TOI-brexit-trump"/>
===South Africa===
Health care and education in South Africa was substantially compromised during the presidency of [[Thabo Mbeki]] due to his [[HIV/AIDS denialism]].
===United Kingdom=== An early use of the phrase in British politics was in March 2012 by [[Scottish Labour]] [[Member of Scottish Parliament|MSP]] [[Iain Gray]] in criticising the difference between [[Scottish National Party]]'s claims and official statistics.<ref name="Gray">{{cite news|title=Beware the black art of post-truth politics|author=Iain Gray|url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/opinion/iain-gray-beware-the-black-art-of-post-truth-politics-1-2146059|date=1 March 2012|accessdate=11 July 2016|newspaper=The Scotsman}}</ref> Scottish Labour leader [[Jim Murphy]] also described an undercurrent of post-truth politics in which people "cheerfully [[shooting the messenger|shot the messenger]]" when presented with facts that didn't support their viewpoint, seeing it among pro-independence campaigners in the [[2014 Scottish independence referendum]], [[Jeremy Corbyn]] supporters in the [[Labour Party (UK) leadership election, 2015|2015 Labour leadership election]], and Leave campaigners in the then-upcoming EU membership referendum.<ref name="Murphy">{{cite news|url=http://www.newstatesman.com/politics/uk/2015/09/we-live-volatile-age-post-truth-politics-and-so-brexit-cannot-be-ruled-out|title=We live in a volatile age of post-truth politics – and so Brexit cannot be ruled out|author=Jim Murphy|newspaper=New Statesman|date=23 September 2015|accessdate=11 July 2016}}</ref>
Post-truth politics has been retroactively identified in the [[lead-up to the Iraq War]],<ref name="Dunt">{{cite web|title=Post-truth politics is driving us mad |url=http://www.politics.co.uk/blogs/2016/06/29/post-truth-politics-is-driving-us-mad|date=29 June 2016|accessdate=11 July 2016|publisher=politics.co.uk|author=Ian Dunt}}</ref> particularly after the [[Chilcot Report]], published in July 2016, concluded that [[Tony Blair]] misrepresented [[military intelligence]] to support his view that [[Iraq and weapons of mass destruction|Iraq's chemical weapons program]] was advanced.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/jul/08/iraq-war-tony-blair-creativity-chilcot-inquiry|title=Millions of us knew the Iraq war would be a catastrophe. Why didn't Tony Blair?|quote=Blair's creative way with the facts seems in retrospect to be the beginning of the sort of post-truth politics we have seen in the recent Brexit debate, where fiction and reality were treated by Nigel Farage, Boris Johnson and their like as essentially interchangeable.|date=8 July 2016|accessdate=11 July 2016|newspaper=The Guardian|author=Max Richter}}</ref><ref name="NSIraq">{{cite news|url=http://www.newstatesman.com/politics/uk/2016/07/leader-iraq-war-and-its-aftermath|title=Leader: The Iraq War and its aftermath|date=6 July 2016|accessdate=11 July 2016|newspaper=New Statesman}}</ref>
The phrase became widely used during the [[United Kingdom European Union membership referendum, 2016|2016 UK EU membership referendum]] to describe the Leave campaign.<ref name="Freedland-nojoke"/><ref name="WaPo-era"/><ref name="Dunt"/><ref name="Wollaston"/><ref name="Mirror-350m">{{cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/post-truth-politics-michael-gove-8111335|title=Post-truth politics: Michael Gove accused of 'importing Trump campaign' to Britain with £350m a week claim|newspaper=The Mirror|date=3 June 2016|accessdate=11 July 2016|author=Mikey Smith, Rachel Bishop}}</ref> [[Faisal Islam]], political editor for [[Sky News]], said that [[Michael Gove]] used "post-fact politics" that were imported from the Trump campaign; in particular, Gove's comment in an interview that "I think people in this country have had enough of experts..." was singled out as illustrative of a post-truth trend, although this is only part of a longer statement.<ref name="WaPo-era"/><ref name="Mirror-350m"/><ref>[[Matthew Flinders (academic)|Matthew Flinders]], [http://blog.oup.com/2016/07/post-political-democracy-uk-referendum Post-truth, post-political, post-democracy: the tragedy of the UK's referendum on the European Union], ''OUPBlog'' ([[Oxford University Press]] (3 July 2016).</ref> Similarly, [[Arron Banks]], the founder of the unofficial [[Leave.EU]] campaign, said that "facts don't work ... You've got to connect with people emotionally. It's the Trump success."<ref name="Deacon"/> [[Andrea Leadsom]]—a prominent campaigner for Leave in the EU referendum and one of the two final candidates in the [[Conservative Party (UK) leadership election, 2016|Conservative leadership election]]—has been singled out as a post-truth politician,<ref name="Deacon"/> especially after she denied having disparaged rival [[Theresa May]]'s childlessness in an interview with ''[[The Times]]'' in spite of transcript evidence.<ref name="Viner"/>
===United States=== In its original formulation, the phrase "post-truth politics" was used to describe the paradoxical situation in the United States where the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]], which enforced stricter [[party discipline]] than the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]], was nevertheless able to present itself as more [[bipartisan]], since individual Democrats were more likely to support Republican policies than vice versa.<ref name="Coining"/> The term was used by [[Paul Krugman]] in ''[[The New York Times]]'' to describe [[Mitt Romney presidential campaign, 2012|Mitt Romney's 2012 presidential campaign]] in which certain claims—such as that [[Barack Obama]] had cut defense spending and that he had embarked on an "apology tour"—continued to be repeated long after they had been debunked.<ref name="Krugman">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/12/23/opinion/krugman-the-post-truth-campaign.html|title=The Post-Truth Campaign|date=23 December 2011|author=Paul Krugman|newspaper=The New York Times}}</ref> Other forms of scientific [[denialism]] in modern American politics include the [[anti-vaxxer]] movement, and the [[Genetically modified food controversies|belief that existing genetically modified foods are harmful]]<ref>{{Cite journal|url=http://yoelinbar.net/papers/gmo_absolute.pdf|title=Evidence for Absolute Moral Opposition to Genetically Modified Food in the United States|first1=Sydney E.|last1=Scott|first2=Yoel|last2=Inbar|first3=Paul|last3=Rozin|journal=Perspectives on Psychological Science|date=2016|volume=11|issue=3|pages=315–324|doi=10.1177/1745691615621275|pmid=27217243}}</ref> despite a strong scientific consensus that no currently marketed GMO foods have any negative health effects.<ref>See {{section link|Denialism|Genetically modified foods}} for extensive citations.</ref> The [[health freedom movement]] in the U.S. resulted in the passage of the bipartisan [[Dietary Supplement Health and Education Act of 1994]], which allows the sale of dietary supplements without any evidence that they are safe or effective for the purposes consumers expect, though the FDA has begun regulation of [[homeopathic]] products.
In a review for the ''[[Harvard Gazette]]'', Christopher Robichaud—a lecturer in ethics and public policy at [[Harvard Kennedy School]]—described [[conspiracy theories]] about the legitimacy of elections and politicians, such as the "[[Barack Obama citizenship conspiracy theories|birther]]" idea that [[Barack Obama]] is not a [[Natural-born-citizen clause|natural-born U.S. citizen]],<!--, and claims from the [[Bernie Sanders]] [[Bernie Sanders presidential campaign, 2016|presidential campaign]] that the [[Democratic Party presidential primaries, 2016|Democratic Party candidate selection]] was rigged towards [[Hillary Clinton]]--> as one side-effect of post-truth politics. Robichaud also contrasted the behaviour of the candidates with that following the contested result of the [[United States presidential election, 2000|2000 election]], in which [[Al Gore]] conceded and encouraged his supporters to accept the result of ''[[Bush v. Gore]]''.<ref name="Harvard-politics"/> Similarly, [[Rob Boston]], writing for ''[[The Humanist]]'' saw a rise in conspiracy theories across American public life, including [[Barack Obama citizenship conspiracy theories|Birtherism]], [[climate change denial]]ism, and [[Creation–evolution controversy|rejecting evolution]], which he identified as a result of post-truth politics, noting that the existence of extensive and widely available evidence against these conspiracy theories had not slowed their growth.<ref name="Humanist"/>
In 2016, the "post-truth" label was especially widely used to describe the [[Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016|presidential campaign of Donald Trump]], including by Professor [[Daniel W. Drezner]] in ''[[The Washington Post]]'',<ref name="WaPo-era"/> [[Jonathan Freedland]] in ''[[The Guardian]]'',<ref name="Freedland-nojoke">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/13/boris-johnson-donald-trump-post-truth-politician|title=Post-truth politicians such as Donald Trump and Boris Johnson are no joke |author=Jonathan Freedland|date=13 May 2016|accessdate=11 July 2016|newspaper=The Guardian}}</ref> [[Chris Cillizza]] in ''[[The Independent]]'',<ref name="Indy"/> Jeet Heer in ''[[The New Republic]]'',<ref>{{Citation | last = Heer | first = Jeet | date = 1 December 2015 | title = Donald Trump Is Not a Liar; He's something worse: a bullshit artist | magazine = The New Republic | url = https://newrepublic.com/article/124803/donald-trump-not-liar | accessdate = 22 July 2016 }}</ref> and [[James Kirchick]] in the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'',<ref name="LATimes">{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/opinion/op-ed/la-oe-kirchick-brexit-trump-20160629-snap-story.html|title=What Trump and the Brexiteers have in common |author=James Kerchick|date=29 June 2016|accessdate=11 July 2016|newspaper=Los Angeles Times}}</ref> and by several professors of government and history at Harvard.<ref name="Harvard-politics"/> In 2017, ''[[The New York Times]]'', ''The Washington Post'', and others, have pointed out lies or falsehoods in Trump's statements after the election.<ref name="NYT-20170623">{{cite news |last1=Leonhardt |first1=David |last2=Thompson |first2=Stuart A. |title=Trump’s Lies |url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2017/06/23/opinion/trumps-lies.html |work=[[New York Times]] |date=23 June 2017 |accessdate=24 June 2017 }}</ref><ref name="NYT-20170427">{{cite news |last=Qui |first=Linda |title=Fact-Checking President Trump Through His First 100 Days |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/29/us/politics/fact-checking-president-trump-through-his-first-100-days.html |date=27 April 2017 |work=[[New York Times]] |accessdate=25 June 2017 }}</ref><ref name="WP-20170501">{{cite news |last1=Kessler |first1=Glenn |last2=Lee |first2=Michelle Ye Hee |title=Fact Checker Analysis - President Trump’s first 100 days: The fact check tally |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/fact-checker/wp/2017/05/01/president-trumps-first-100-days-the-fact-check-tally/ |date=1 May 2017 |work=[[Washington Post]] |accessdate=25 June 2017 }}</ref><ref name="CT-20170624">{{cite news |last1=Drinkard |first1=Jim |last2=Woodward |first2=Calvin |title=Fact check: Trump's missions unaccomplished despite his claims |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/politics/factcheck/ct-fact-check-trump-missions-20170624-story.html |date=24 June 2017 |work=[[Chicago Tribune]] |accessdate=25 June 2017 }}</ref> Former president Barack Obama stated that the new media ecosystem "means everything is true and nothing is true".<ref name="NYM-20161128">{{cite web |last=Remnick |first=David |title=Obama Reckons With A Trump Presidency |url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2016/11/28/obama-reckons-with-a-trump-presidency |date=28 November 2016 |work=[[The New Yorker]] |accessdate=24 January 2017}}</ref>
===Environmental politics=== Although the [[scientific opinion on climate change|consensus among scientists]] is that [[global warming|human activities contribute to global warming]], several political parties around the world have made [[climate change denial]] a basis of their policies. These parties have been accused of using post-truth techniques to attack environmental measures meant to combat climate changes to benefit industry donors.<ref name="WasteManagement">{{cite journal|url=http://search.informit.com.au/documentSummary;dn=687980493190405;res=IELENG|last=Connor|first=John|title=Climate change and post-truth politics|journal=Waste Management and Environment|volume=22|issue=10|date=November 2011}}</ref> During the course of the most recent 2016 election, the United States has seen numerous climate change deniers rise to power, such as new [[United States Environmental Protection Agency|Environmental Protection Agency]] head [[Scott Pruitt]] replacing Barack Obama's appointee [[Gina McCarthy]]. In Australia, the repeal of [[Carbon pricing in Australia|carbon pricing]] by the [[Abbott ministry|government]] of [[Tony Abbott]] was described as "the nadir of post-truth politics" by ''[[The Age]]''.<ref name="Age-abbott"/>
==Solutions== {{undue|date=March 2018|section|reason=What makes this professor's theory notable and no other?}} Both technology companies and governments have started to make efforts to tackle the challenge of "post-truth politics". In an article for the journal ''[[Global Policy]]'', professor [[Nayef Al-Rodhan]] suggested four particular responses:<ref>''[http://www.globalpolicyjournal.com/blog/07/06/2017/post-truth-politics-fifth-estate-and-securitization-fake-news Nayef Al-Rodhan, "Post-Truth Politics, the Fifth Estate and the Securitization of Fake News]'', Global Policy Journal, 7th June 2017</ref>
# ''Improve the technological tools for fact checking.'' For example, Germany has already asked [[Facebook]] to introduce a [[fake news]] filtering tool. # ''Greater involvement and visibility for scientists and the scientific community.'' The UK, for instance, has a series of Parliamentary committees at which scientists are called to testify, and present their research to inform policy-making.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://medium.com/oxford-university/policy-making-and-parliament-in-an-era-of-post-truth-1086d153e619 |title=Policy-making and parliament in an era of ‘post-truth’ |publisher=Medium.com |date=2017-02-28 |accessdate=2018-03-26}}</ref> # ''Stronger government action.'' In countries such as the Czech Republic, new units have been set up to tackle fake news.<ref>{{cite web|author=Robert Tait in Prague |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/dec/28/czech-republic-to-fight-fake-news-with-specialist-unit |title=Czech Republic to fight 'fake news' with specialist unit | Media |publisher=The Guardian |date= |accessdate=2018-03-26}}</ref> The most important challenge here is to ensure that such state-led efforts are not used as a tool for censorship. # ''Securitizing fake news.'' It is important to treat post-truth politics as a matter of security and devise global efforts to counter this phenomenon. In March 2017, the United Nations Special Rapporteur on Freedom of Opinion and Expression, the OSCE, and the Organization for American States issued a Joint Declaration on "Freedom of Expression and Fake News, Disinformation and Propaganda" to warn against the effects of fake news but, at the same time, condemn any attempts at state-mandated censorship.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=56336#.WVOi61t9671 |title=Amid rise of ‘fake news,’ authorities should ensure truthful info reaches public – UN, regional experts | UN News |publisher=Un.org |date=2017-03-10 |accessdate=2018-03-26}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Kutner |first=Max |url=http://www.newsweek.com/edward-snowden-jack-dorsey-twitter-periscope-531573 |title=Edward Snowden: Fight ‘Fake News’ With Truth, Not Censorship |publisher=Newsweek.com |date= |accessdate=2018-03-26}}</ref>

{{Wiktionary|predicable}} '''Predicable''' (Lat. praedicabilis, that which may be stated or affirmed, sometimes called ''quinque voces'' or ''five words'') is, in [[term logic|scholastic logic]], a term applied to a [[Categorization|classification]] of the possible relations in which a [[Predicate (logic)|predicate]] may stand to its [[Subject (philosophy)|subject]]. It is not to be confused with '[[praedicamenta]]', the [[scholasticism|schoolmen's]] term for [[Aristotle]]'s ten [[Categories (Aristotle)|Categories]].
The list given by the schoolmen and generally adopted by modern logicians is based on the original fivefold classification given by Aristotle ([[Topics (Aristotle)|Topics]], a iv. 101 b 17-25): [[definition]] (''horos''), [[Genus (philosophy)|genus]] (''genos''), [[differentia]] (''diaphora''), [[property (logic)|property]] (''idion''), and [[accident (philosophy)|accident]] (''sumbebekos'').<ref>Strictly Aristotle's classification is into four as διαφορά ([[differentia|''diaphora'']]) really belongs to γένος ([[Genus (philosophy)|''genos'']]).</ref> The scholastic classification, obtained from [[Anicius Manlius Severinus Boethius|Boëthius]]'s Latin version of [[Porphyry (philosopher)|Porphyry]]'s ''[[Isagoge]]'', modified Aristotle's by substituting [[species (logic)|species]] (''eidos'') for definition. Both classifications are of [[Universal (metaphysics)|universals]], [[concept]]s or general [[terminology|terms]], [[proper names]] of course being excluded. There is, however, a radical difference between the two systems. The standpoint of the Aristotelian classification is the predication of one universal concerning another. The Porphyrian, by introducing species, deals with the predication of universals concerning individuals (for species is necessarily predicated of the individual), and thus created difficulties from which the Aristotelian is free (see below).
The Aristotelian classification is: * The ''definition'' of anything is the statement of its [[essence]] (Arist. τὸ τί ἦν εἶναι), i.e., that which makes it what it is: e.g., a triangle is a three-sided rectilinear figure. * ''Genus'' is that part of the essence which is also predicable of other things different from them in kind. A triangle is a rectilinear figure; i.e., in fixing the genus of a thing, we subsume it under a higher universal, of which it is a species. * ''Differentia'' is that part of the essence which distinguishes one species from another. As compared with quadrilaterals, hexagons, and so on, all of which are rectilinear figures, a triangle is differentiated as having three sides. * A ''property'' is an attribute which is common to all the members of a class, but is not part of its essence (i.e., need not be given in its definition). The fact that the interior angles of all triangles are equal to two right angles is not part of the definition, but is universally true. * An ''accident'' is an attribute which may or may not belong to a subject. That the colour of a human's hair should be black, for instance, is an accident, for blackness-of-hair belongs in no way to the essence of humanity, nor do all humans have black hair.
This classification, though it is of high value in the clearing up of our conceptions of the essential contrasted with the accidental, the relation of genus, differentia and definition and so forth, is of more significance in connection with abstract sciences, especially mathematics, than for the physical sciences. It is superior on the whole to the Porphyrian scheme, which has grave defects. As has been said, the Porphyrian scheme classifies universals as predicates of individuals and thus involves the difficulties which gave rise to the controversy between realism and nominalism. How are we to distinguish species from genus? Napoleon was a Frenchman, a man, an animal. In the second place how do we distinguish property and accident? Many so-called accidents are predicable necessarily of any particular persons. This difficulty gave rise to the distinction of separable and inseparable accidents, which is one of considerable difficulty.
Some Aristotelian examples may be briefly mentioned. In the true statement “Man is a rational animal,” the predicate is convertible with the subject and states its essence; therefore, “rational animal” is the definition of man. The statements “Man is an animal” and “Man is rational,” while true, are not convertible; their predicate terms, however, are parts of the definition and hence are the genus and differentia of man. On the other hand, the statement “Man is capable of learning grammar” is true and convertible; but “capable of learning grammar” does not state the essence of man and is therefore a property of man. The true statement “Man is featherless” offers an example of an accident. Its predicate is not convertible with its subject, nor is it part of the definition; accordingly, it expresses only an accidental characteristic of man.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/predicable |title=Predicable, Logic |publisher=Encycopledia Britannica |access-date=March 29, 2018}}</ref>

'''Prescriptivity''' is a term used in [[meta-ethics]] to state that when an evaluative judgment or decision is made it must either prescribe or condemn. The word implies that these judgments (and the prescription and condemnation) logically commit us to certain ways of living. Contrary to popular opinion prescriptivity does not just describe or categorize decisions for example; "You ought to do this" (used evaluatively) [[logical consequence|logically entails]] the imperative "Do this."
==Universal Prescriptivism== Prescriptivity is one of the five (prescriptivity, universalizability, overridingness, publicity, and practicability) axioms of Formal [[Ethics]].{{Citation needed|date=January 2011}} When combined with Universalizability, prescriptivity becomes [[Universal prescriptivism]]. Universal precriptivism combines these two methods of thinking, combining evaluative judgments (which commit us to making similar judgments about similar cases) and prescription and condemnation when the judgment is at last made. This enables us to think in a very powerful and [[Rationality|rational]] way about ethical and moral issues.

{{Orphan|date=June 2016}}
The '''principle of maximum caliber''' ('''MaxCal''') or '''maximum path entropy principle''', suggested by [[E. T. Jaynes]],<ref name="Jaynes1980" /> can be considered as a generalization of the [[principle of maximum entropy]]. It postulates that the most unbiased probability distribution of paths is the one that maximizes their [[Shannon entropy]]. This entropy of paths is sometimes called the "caliber" of the system, and is given by the path integral
: <math> S[\rho[x()]] = \int D_x \,\, \rho[x()] \, \ln {\rho[x()] \over \pi[x()]}</math>
== History ==
The principle of maximum caliber was proposed by [[Edwin T. Jaynes]] in 1980,<ref name="Jaynes1980" /> in an article titled ''The Minimum Entropy Production Principle'' over the context of to find a principle for to derive the [[non-equilibrium statistical mechanics]].
== Mathematical formulation ==
The principle of maximum caliber can be considered as a generalization of the [[principle of maximum entropy]] defined over the paths space, the caliber <math> S </math> is of the form
: <math> S[\rho[x()]] = \int D_x \rho[x()] \ln {\rho[x()] \over \pi[x()]}</math>
where for ''n''-constraints
: <math> \int D_x \rho[x()] A_n[x()] = \langle A_n[x()] \rangle = a_n </math>
it is shown that the probability functional is
: <math> \rho[x()] = \exp\left\{ - \sum_{i=0}^n \alpha_n A_n[x()] \right\}.</math>
In the same way, for n dynamical constraints defined in the interval <math> t \in [0,T] </math> of the form
: <math> \int D_x \rho[x()] L_n(x(t),\dot x(t), t ) = \langle L_n(x(t),\dot x(t),t ) \rangle = \ell(t)</math>
it is shown that the probability functional is
: <math> \rho[x()] = \exp\left\{ - \sum_{i=0}^n \int_0^T dt \, \alpha_n(t) L_n(x(t),\dot x(t), t ) \right\}. </math>
==Maximum caliber and statistical mechanics==
Following the hypothesis of Jaynes, there are publications in which it appears as the principle of maximum caliber it is framed in the context of creating a statistical representation of systems with many degrees of freedom.<ref name="Presse2013" /><ref name="Hazoglou2015" /><ref name="Davis2015" />
==Notes== {{reflist|refs=
<ref name=Jaynes1980>[http://www.annualreviews.org/doi/pdf/10.1146/annurev.pc.31.100180.003051 Jaynes, E. T. (1980) ''The Minimum Entropy Production Principle'' , Annu. Rev. Phys. Chem. 31, 579.]</ref>
<ref name=Presse2013>[http://journals.aps.org/rmp/abstract/10.1103/RevModPhys.85.1115 Steve Pressé, Kingshuk Ghosh, Julian Lee, and Ken A. Dill (2013), '' Principles of maximum entropy and maximum caliber in statistical physics '', Rev. Mod. Phys. 85, 1115.]</ref>
<ref name=Hazoglou2015>[http://scitation.aip.org/content/aip/journal/jcp/143/5/10.1063/1.4928193 Michael J. Hazoglou, Valentin Walther, Purushottam D. Dixit and Ken A. Dill (2015), Communication: Maximum caliber is a general variational principle for nonequilibrium statistical mechanics, J. Chem. Phys. 143, 051104.]</ref>
<ref name=Davis2015>[http://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.1088/1751-8113/48/42/425003/meta Davis S., González D. (2015), ''Hamiltonian formalism and path entropy maximization'', Journal of Physics A-Mathematical and Theoretical Vol. 48 Num. 42]</ref> }}

{{other uses}} {{redirect|Mocking|other uses|Mock (disambiguation){{!}}Mock}} [[File:Colorful Clown 3.jpg|thumb|This ridiculously small hat is incongruous with the man's head size.|200px]]
To be '''ridiculous''' is to be something which is highly incongruous or inferior, sometimes deliberately so to make people laugh or get their attention, and sometimes unintendedly so as to be considered laughable and earn or provoke ridicule and derision. It comes from the 1540s Latin "ridiculosus" meaning "laughable", from "ridiculus" meaning "that which excites laughter", and from "ridere" meaning "to laugh".<ref name=DC>[http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/ridiculous Dictionary.com]</ref> "Ridiculous" is an adjective describing "the ridiculous".
In common usage, "ridiculousness" is used as a synonym for [[absurdity]] or [[nonsense]].<ref>[http://www.thefreedictionary.com/nonsensical Free Dictionary]</ref><ref>[http://thesaurus.com/browse/illogicality Thesaurus.com]</ref> From a historical and technical viewpoint, "absurdity" is associated with argumentation and reasoning, "nonsense" with [[semantics]] and [[Meaning (linguistics)|meaning]], while "ridiculous" is most associated with laughter, superiority, deformity, and incongruity. ''[[Reductio ad absurdum]]'' is a valid method of [[argument]], while ''[[appeal to ridicule|reductio ad ridiculum]]'' is invalid. Argument by [[invective]] declaration of ridiculous is invalid, while arguments involving declarations of nonsense may summarize a [[logical reasoning|cogent]] semantic problem with lack or meaning or [[ambiguity]].
Historically, the ridiculous was central to initial theories of humor and laughter as first put forth by philosopher [[Thomas Hobbes]]. It is currently used in the [[theories of humor|theory of humor]] to create laughter, shock, parody, or satire. Reactions to the ridiculous have been studied in [[psychology]] for its effects on memory, attention, and attitude in social hierarchies. These studies have been applied to the theory of advertisement regarding attention, memory, and alleviation of preexisting negative attitudes toward products. The ridiculous is often contrasted with the [[Sublime (philosophy)|sublime]], one of extreme inferiority, the other of extreme superiority, and often one can suddenly move from one extreme state to the other.
== Humor == {{Further information|Theory of humor}}
=== History: Incongruity, the superiority theory of humor, and deformity === The ridiculous often has extreme incongruity (things that are not thought to belong next to each other) or inferiority, e.g., "when something that was dignified is reduced to a ridiculous position (here noting the element of the incongruous), so that laughter is most intense when we escape from a 'coerced solemnity'."<ref>''Humour, Jokes and the Statement'', Journal of Human Values, 2006, S Acharya, [http://jhv.sagepub.com/content/12/2/179.short]</ref><ref>[http://bjaesthetics.oxfordjournals.org/content/4/3/284 British Journal of Aesthetics, (1964) 4 (3), Harold Osborne, p.284]</ref> For [[Aristotle]], we laugh at inferior or [[unattractiveness|ugly]] individuals, because we feel a joy at being superior to them.<ref>''Poetics'', 1449a, p. 34-35.</ref> [[Socrates]] was reported by [[Plato]] as saying that the ridiculous was characterized by a display of self-ignorance.<ref>Plato, ''Philebus'' 49b ff.</ref> [[Deformity]] was considered by some to be essential to the ridiculous.<ref>Laughter as a Test of Truth in Enlightenment Satire'', Werner von Koppenfels</ref><ref name=HEL>A history of English Laughter: Laughter from Beowulf to Beckett and Beyond, Manfred Pfister</ref> Psychological theories of humor include the "incongruity theory" and the "superiority theory", the latter of which the philosopher Thomas Hobbes was an early proponent.<ref>The Perception of Humor, Willibald Ruch, Emotions, qualia, and consciousness, Biocybernetics, VOl. 10</ref><ref>How Many Feminists Does It Take To Make A Joke? Sexist Humor and What's Wrong With It, Memo Bergmann, Hypatia, Vol.1, Issue 1, March 1986</ref><ref>Humor as a Double‐Edged Sword: Four Functions of Humor in Communication, JC Meyer, Communication Theory, Volume 10, Issue 3, pages 310–331, August 2000</ref> Hobbes claimed that laughter was either caused spontaneously, or by seeing a deformed thing to which one compares themselves and laugh as a form of self applause; "a sudden glory arising from sudden conception of some eminency in ourselves, by comparison of the infirmities of others." <ref name=HEL/> The Right Reverend [[William Warburton]], [[Lord Bishop]] of [[Gloucester]] said in the early 18th century that, "Nothing is ridiculous but what is deformed".<ref>The divine legation of Moses demonstrated, William Warburton</ref> Using the ridiculous is a method in the theory of humor.<ref>Investigating the humor of gelotophobes: Does feeling ridiculous equal being humorless?, Humor - International Journal of Humor Research. Volume 22, Issue 1-2, Pages 111–143, ISSN (Online) 1613-3722, ISSN (Print) 0933-1719, {{doi|10.1515/HUMR.2009.006}}, /February/2009, Willibald Ruch, Ursula Beermann, [http://www.reference-global.com/doi/abs/10.1515/HUMR.2009.006?journalCode=humr]{{dead link|date=February 2017}}</ref>
Although common usage now considers "absurdity" to be synonymous with "ridiculousness", Hobbes discussed the two concepts as different, in that absurdity is viewed as having to do with invalid reasoning, as in [[Hobbes' Table of Absurdity]], while ridiculousness has to do with laughter, superiority, ridicule, and deformity.
=== Native American Ritual Clown === {{Further information|Ritual clown}} The [[Ritual clown]] ([[Heyókȟa]]) in some [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native American]] culture uses the painfully ridiculous, and is believed to become closer to the gods by its [[:wikt:primordial|primordial]]ity.<ref>''Native American Postcolonial Psychology'', E Duran, B Duran</ref><ref>Ambigere: The Euro-American Picaro and the Native American Trickster, Melus, The Society for the Study of the Multi-Ethnic Literature of the United States Vol. 17, No. 1, Spring 1991, F Ballinger</ref> Native American clowns are ridiculous in their contrary and rule breaking antics.<ref>The Mythology of Evil Among North American Indian Yuroks and Its Implications for Western Spirituality, Anthropology of Consciousness, Volume 7, Issue 3, pages 15–29, September 1996, Royal Alsup, Stanley Krippne, [https://www.jstor.org/pss/467321]</ref> In the film ''[[Little Big Man (film)|Little Big Man]]'', the sacred clown rides sitting backwards on his horse, "washes" himself with dirt and "dries" himself with water.<ref>Jennifer L. McMahon, B. Steve Csaki, ''The Philosophy of the Western'' (2010), p. 295.</ref> Heyókȟa are thought of as being incongruously backwards-forwards, upside-down, or contrary in nature. This spirit is often manifest by doing things backwards or unconventionally—riding a horse backwards, wearing clothes inside-out, or speaking backwards. For example, if food were scarce, a Heyókȟa would sit around and complain about how full he was; during a baking hot heat wave a Heyókȟa would shiver with cold and put on gloves and cover himself with a thick blanket. Similarly, when it is 40 degrees below freezing he will wander around naked for hours complaining that it is too hot.{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}}
==== Parody and satire in social commentary ==== {{Further information|Parody|Satire}} The ridiculous can use uses both physical and conceptual inferiority and incongruity of juxtaposition to create [[parody]] and [[satire]].
In ''[[Candide]]'', [[Voltaire]] parodies [[Leibniz]]'s argument for the [[existence of evil]] under a benign God using ''"ridiculous rationalizations of evil"''.<ref name="TCD">''"ridiculous rationalizations of evil"''. Teaching Candide-A Debate, The French Review, Vol 61, No. 5, 1988, Theodore E. D. Braun, Felicia Sturzer, Martine Darmon Meyer, [https://www.jstor.org/pss/393842]</ref> Leibniz claimed that God is constrained by logic, and created the best of all ''[[possible worlds]]''. After being reduced from a "[[dignity|dignified]]" state to its opposite, the [[optimistic]] Dr. [[Panglossian|Pangloss]] (representing Leibniz) finds cause to consider his undignified position to be the best of all possible worlds, noting his own particular current happiness, which he argues could not have been attained without experiencing the atrocities in the previous narrative; his optimistic attitude is extremely incongruous with his experiences and extremely inferior undignified ultimate condition.<ref name= TCD/>
In [[Stanley Kubrick]]'s ''[[2001: A Space Odyssey]]'', apelike humans and their behavior are juxtaposed next to streamlined advanced technology with a highly avant garde score by composer [[György Ligeti]]; Ligeti also used ridiculous juxtaposition in his scores to create parody,<ref>Blending the Sublime and the Ridiculous: A Study of Parody in György Ligeti's Le Grand Macabre, Sewell, Amanda J, [https://web.archive.org/web/20110720021116/http://etd.ohiolink.edu/view.cgi?bgsu1150987452]</ref> and this tool was frequently used by composer [[Peter Maxwell Davies]].
=== Deformity and incongruity in performance as social commentary, and lifestyle ===
==== Japanese Butoh dance ==== {{Further information|Butoh}} Japanese [[Butoh]] uses both incongruity and deformity to create ridiculous dance performance and lifestyle; extreme movement methods that are highly incongruous with natural body movement in its dance and everyday lifestyle, as well as in its clothing, actions, costume and set design that is highly incongruous with societal norms, which often shock the audience or visitor, and are sometimes considered not only ridiculous, but incongruently "bizarre and [[beauty|beautiful]]" or "[[elegant]] and [[grotesque]]".<ref>''The Bizarre World of Butoh'', San Fransciso Weekly</ref><ref>''The Bizzare and the Beautiful'', Los Angeles Times, 1989</ref>
==== Theatre of the Ridiculous ==== {{Further information|Theatre of the Ridiculous}} The Theatre of the Ridiculous uses highly incongruous stage settings and incongruous costumes such as [[cross dressing]] to disturb or create shock in the audience.<ref>Conquest of the Ridiculous:Ronald Tavel, John Vaccaro and Charles Ludlam, WarholStars, [http://www.warholstars.org/ridiculous.html]</ref>
== Psychology: attention, memory, and attitudes == Psychologists have studied human response to the ridiculous and its effects on attention and memory.<ref name="ReferenceA">The Psychology of Advertising, Walter Dill Scott, 1910</ref><ref>The Ancient Art of Memory: Usefulness in Treatment, Bernard M. Patten, Archives of Neurology, 1972;26(1):25-31, [http://archneur.ama-assn.org/cgi/content/abstract/26/1/25]</ref>
===Advertising=== The ridiculous is used in advertising to [[Psychological manipulation|manipulate]] attention and attitudes toward products.<ref name="ReferenceA"/><ref>Music for advertising effects, Psychology and Marketing, Volume 1, Issue 3-4, 1984, S Hecker</ref>
== Juxtaposition with the sublime {{anchor| Ridiculous and the sublime}} == The ridiculous is sometimes contrasted to the sublime where something with one quality is thought of as approaching, or likely to change to, the other.
[[Thomas Paine]], writing in ''[[The Age of Reason]]'' in 1795, said ''The sublime and the ridiculous are often so nearly related, that it is difficult to class them separately. One step above the sublime, makes the ridiculous; and one step above the ridiculous, makes the sublime again.''<ref name=odp>{{cite book|chapter=sublime | title=The Oxford Dictionary of Proverbs | editor=Jennifer Speake | publisher=Oxford University Press | year=2009 | url=http://www.oxfordreference.com/views/ENTRY.html?subview=Main&entry=t90.e2157| accessdate=2011-02-13}} ''Available online to subscribers''</ref>
[[Napoleon]], reflecting on the state of his existence following his retreat from Moscow in 1812, famously remarked to Polish ambassador [[Dominique-Georges-Frédéric Dufour de Pradt|D. G. De Pradt]]: ''Du sublime au ridicule il n'y a qu'un pas'' (''There is only one step from the sublime to the ridiculous'').<ref name=DC/><ref name=odp /><ref>The Columbia Dictionary of Quotations, Robert Andrews</ref><ref>British Journal of Aesthetics, Aesthetics (1964) 4 (3), Harold Osborne, p. 284-5, [http://bjaesthetics.oxfordjournals.org/content/4/3/284]</ref>
=== Reduction to the ridiculous, or "reductio ad ridiculum" === {{Further information|Appeal to ridicule|Red herring|straw man}} Reduction to the ridiculous (Latin: "reductio ad ridiculum", also called "Appeal to ridicule", "appeal to mockery", or "the Horse Laugh") is a logical fallacy which presents the opponent's argument in a way that grossly misrepresents it and appears ridiculous next to it, often so misrepresentative as to create a [[straw man]] argument, rather than addressing the argument itself.<ref name=WT>''Wishful Thinking and Other Philosophical Reflections'', Nicholas Rescher, 2009</ref> For example, in arguing against [[idealism]], with its sophisticated arguments that the world was not real but only existed in the [[mind]], philosopher [[Dr. Johnson]] famously kicked a stone.<ref Name=WT/>
Contrasting ridiculousness with absurdity in [[reasoning]], ''Reductio ad ridiculum'' is an invalid method of argument, while ''reductio ad absurdum'' is a valid method.
=== Invective === Arguments are often simply dismissed by calling them "ridiculous" as invective, without further argumentation.<ref name=WT/> Philosopher [[Friedrich Nietzsche]] often dismissed philosophical positions by calling them "ridiculous" without further argument given.<ref name=WT/>
